newsitem.title: CHINA: China sees bank deposits rising 22.5 pct in 1997.
newsitem.headline: China sees bank deposits rising 22.5 pct in 1997.

text.p: Personal bank deposits in China are projected to grow by 22.5 percent this year to reach 4.72 trillion yuan at the end of 1997, the State Information Centre said in a forecast published in the Market Daily on Tuesday.
Personal bank deposits of urban residents increased by 886.9 billion yuan in 1996, or 29.9 percent, to 3.8531 trillion yuan at the year-end, the State Information Centre said.
It attributed the continued increase in deposits to strong economic growth that was fuelling rising incomes as well as to stability in the consumer market.

The slower rate of growth in deposits in 1997 could be attributed to the virtual elimination of interest rate subsidies on time deposits as well as the increase in issue of state debt, which was expected to absorb about 100 billion yuan of personal deposits, it said.
In 1997, China planned to issue about 123 billion yuan of non-tradeable debt that could be bought by private investors, up by 93 million yuan from last year.
In 1997, the proportion of non-tradeable debt in the total issue would be about 50 percent compared with 15.4 percent last year, it said.
